sections.title: Topic Vocabulary
rows: to defeat someone in a game, competition, election, or battle
England needed to beat Germany to get to the final.
any game in which you move objects around on a special board
I think that Trivial Pursuit is my favourite board game.
the person who is in charge of a team or organisation
She was captain of the Olympic swimming team.
to invite someone to compete or fight
The girls challenged the boys to a cricket match.
something that needs a lot of skill, energy, and determination to deal with or achieve
I felt I needed a new challenge at work.
someone who has won an important competition, especially in sport
He finally became the world heavyweight boxing champion.
to behave dishonestly, or to not obey rules
Kids have always found ways of cheating in school exams.
serious music that is played on instruments such as the piano and the violin
I love classical music, like Beethoven.
an organisation for people who take part in a particular activity, or the building that they use
Why don't you join a chess club?
someone who trains a sports player or team
After playing for ten years, Barry became a baseball coach.
an organised event in which people try to win prizes by being better than other people
He'd entered a competition in the local newspaper.
an event at which an orchestra, band, or musician plays or sings in front of an audience
Did you hear that the Rolling Stones did a concert in China?
failure to win a competition or to succeed in doing something
I saw a really entertaining programme on TV last night.
traditional music from a particular country or region, or music played in a traditional style
What I like about folk music is the sound of the guitar.
a small set of musicians who play pop music
My brother has got his own group and they play in our local area.
a room or club with equipment for doing physical exercises
I'm thinking of joining a gym.
get enjoyment from an activity that is not important or serious
We haven't had such fun for years.
to make someone want to know about or take part in something
an activity that you enjoy doing when you are not working
Tell us about your interests and hobbies.
someone who belongs to a group or an organisation
Are you a member of the golf club?
someone who is competing against you
His opponent received only 36 per cent of the vote.
to prepare or arrange an activity or event
a feeling of happiness, enjoyment, or satisfaction
He smiled with pleasure when she walked in.
someone whose job is to make sure that players in a game obey the rules
The referee blew his whistle and the game began.
a regular pattern of sounds in music
This song has got a really great rhythm.
to do something although you know that something bad could happen as a result
He risked a lot of money on the company.
the possibility that something unpleasant or dangerous might happen
There's a serious risk of an accident on this road.
to get a point in a game or sport
No one scored in the first half.
the number of points that someone gains in a game or test
The final score was 4-3 to United.
to like a particular sports team and always want them to win
I support West Ham - who do you support?
help that you give to a particular idea, organisation, etc
I hope all the students will support our plans to rebuild the school.
a group of people who play a sport or game against another group
Are you in the hockey team this year?
to practise a sport regularly before a match or competition
The players train five days a week.
a game in which players use electronic controls to move images on a television or computer screen
I don't like video games - I'd rather play outside.

sections.title: Phrasal Verbs
rows: The phone rang, but Mark just carried on.
Would you like stay in or eat out tonight?
to stop doing something you regularly do
Ask them if you can play — I'm sure they'll let you join in.
to make a player leave a game
It was a very bad foul and the referee sent the player off.
I've taken up stamp collecting and it's really interesting.
Turn the radio down — I'm trying to work.
We asked our teacher to turn the CD up, so that we could hear it.

sections.title: Prepositional Phrases
rows: I haven't seen George for a long time.
I sing in a band for fun.
In the middle of the stage, there was an elephant.
We arrived at the cinema just in time for the start of the film.
I didn't see it at the cinema, so I'm watching it on DVD tonight.
performing in front of an audience
There were three actors on stage.

sections.title: Word Patterns
rows: I’m bored with watching this film.
Marshall is crazy about video games.
What sports are you good at?
I'm not very keen on spicy food.
This band is popular with teenagers.
What do you feel like doing this weekend?
In my free time, I like to listen to music.
Have you ever taken part in a talent contest?
I read a great book by an English writer about travelling around Europe.
someone who likes something or someone
If you're a fan of Tony DeVito, you'll love this latest album.
In a game against a local school I scored four goals.

sections.title: Word Formation
rows: They say that actions speak louder than words.
I would love to be an actor.
Johnnie is six years old, so he's very active and has a lot of energy.
I've been a bit inactive since I got a job in an office.
You need to be very athletic to play volleyball.
I want to see the athletics at the Olympics.
I watched some children playing in the playground.
My mum spent her childhood in France.
John has got a great collection of football shirts.
I sold my old stamps to a collector.
There isn't much entertainment in the evenings in my town.
The story was all about two heroic young men.
The heroine of the book finally gets married.
Do you have much musical talent?
It's not easy becoming a professional musician.
One of the players was injured when he scored a goal.
My baby brother is very playful.
I love sailing and I try to go every summer.
A sailor helped us put our bags onto the ship.
I sang in the choir when I was young.
The song was sung every morning at school.
What's the name of that song you're singing?
Kylie Minogue is one of my favourite singers.
I love Katy's singing — she's got a good voice.

sections.title: Topic Vocabulary
rows: to succeed in doing or having something
We've achieved what we wanted to do.
the organ inside your head that allows you to think and feel, and controls your body
The illness had affected his brain.
good at learning or understanding things
I'd like to be a doctor, but I'm not clever enough.
to give all your attention to the thing that you are doing
to think about something carefully before you make a decision
At one time I seriously considered leaving.
a series of lessons in an academic subject or a practical skill
You could do a language course abroad.
a course of study at a university, or the qualification that you get after completing the course
She's doing a degree at Exeter University.
if you experience a problem or situation, you have that problem or are in that situation
I'd love to experience being in a submarine.
knowledge and skill that you get by doing a particular job or activity
Do you have any previous experience with children?
someone who has a particular skill or knows a lot about a particular subject
having special skills in or knowledge about something
to say or decide what you think is true, without being certain about it
Whoever guesses correctly will win two tickets to the show.
an occasion when you say what you think is true without being certain
Have a guess and then check it on your calculator.
to pause before doing something because you are nervous or not certain about it
He hesitated for a moment and then knocked on the door.
a statement of something that must be done, or an explanation of how to do or use something
I tried to follow her instructions, but got confused.
My guitar teacher says I'm making a lot of progress.
to check something, so that you can be sure about it
I just wanted to make sure you knew where to go.
to judge the quality of a student's work and write a mark on it
I spent the evening marking essays.
a score or grade that you are given for school work or for how you perform in a competition
What mark did you get for your essay?
existing in the mind, or relating to the mind
Scientists know a lot about the mental development of children.
to be successful in an examination or test
something such as a degree or a diploma that you get when you successfully finish a course of study
Simon left school with no qualifications.
to help someone to remember something
Remind Jenny to bring my CD when she comes.
a spoken or written description of a particular subject, situation, or event
We have to write a short report on the conference.
to study your notes and information again in order to prepare for an examination
I've got a test tomorrow, so I have to revise tonight.
to try to find something or someone by looking carefully
After three days searching, I gave up.
The police have carried out an extensive search of the area.
the ability to do something well, usually as a result of experience and training
Being a doctor demands a lot of skill.
Sophie is a very smart student.
something that you learn or teach at a school, for example English, mathematics, or biology
I'm taking the exam in June.
one of the periods of time that the year is divided into for students
How many weeks is it till the end of term?
to think about something because you want to know more facts
I was wondering about the best place for a holiday.

sections.title: Phrasal Verbs
rows: to draw a line through something
Just cross it out and rewrite it correctly.
to try to find information in a book, etc
I had to look the word up in a dictionary.
He pointed out that we had two hours of free time before dinner.
to say something out loud which you are reading
He read the list of names out.
Rip up this piece of paper when you've finished reading it.
I can't rub it out because I wrote it in pen.
to turn something so the other side is towards you
You may turn over your exam papers now.
to write information on a piece of paper
Do you want to write down my phone number?

sections.title: Prepositional Phrases
rows: I've learnt the song by heart.
Many countries, for instance the UK, don't have identity cards.
In conclusion, I believe that television is a positive invention.
Many people think Greece is hot in the winter but, in fact, it sometimes snows.
Are you in favour of school uniforms?
In general, TV programmes are not educational.

sections.title: Word Patterns
rows: Are you capable of holding your breath under water for two minutes?
Cilla is really talented at singing.
to be dishonest in a game/exam
You should never cheat at cards. / You didn't cheat in the exam, did you?
I think you've confused me with someone else.
Continue with your work and I'll be back in a moment.
I can't cope with all this homework!
Can I help you with that?
Do you know anything about astronomy?
We're learning about dinosaurs at school at the moment.
I really hope you succeed in all your exams.
What's your opinion about/of classical music?
Can I ask you a question about the maths test?

sections.title: Word Formation
rows: The lesson began at ten o'clock.
We'd already begun when Sam arrived.
She lost the game, but she is only a beginner.
I missed the end of the film, but I saw the beginning.
The police officer got an award for bravery.
I've made a few corrections to your article.
I'm good at multiplication, but not division.
Every child should get an education.
Listen carefully to the instructions before you do the exercise.
Do we have to memorise all these irregular verbs?
There's a memorial to Mr Watkins in the school garden.
I'm applying for a job, so could you write me a reference?
I want absolute silence in the exam.
It's very difficult, so I'll simplify it for you.
Simplicity is important in good written communication.

sections.title: Topic Vocabulary
rows: in or to a foreign country
We try to go abroad at least once a year.
a place for someone to stay, live, or work in
The hotel provides accommodation for up to 100 people.
to arrange to have or use something at a particular time in the future
Shall I book a room for you?
a period of time when you are not working and can rest or enjoy yourself
OK, let's take a fifteen-minute break.
to say that something that has been arranged will not now happen
to get on a train, bus, plane, or boat that is travelling somewhere
I caught the next train to London.
a comfortable bus for long journeys
Let's take the coach to Brighton this weekend.
easy for you to do, or suitable for your needs
Travelling underground is fast and convenient.
if a vehicle crashes, or if someone crashes it, it hits something
Three people were killed when their car crashed into a tree.
an accident that happens when a vehicle hits something
He was seriously injured in a car crash.
containing a lot of people or things
a journey on a ship for pleasure, often visiting a series of places
I would love to go on a cruise round the Mediterranean.
to do something later than is planned or expected
They delayed the decision for as long as possible.
a situation in which something happens later or more slowly than you expected
After a long delay, the plane finally took off.
the place where someone or something is going
After eight hours on the road, we finally reached our destination.
a boat that makes short regular journeys between two or more places
They took the ferry to Dover.
The flight from New York to Heathrow took about five hours.
from another country, or in another country
Do you speak any foreign languages?
an area of water next to the land where boats can stop
There were about twenty boats in the harbour.
an occasion when you travel from one place to another, especially over a long distance
We had a long journey ahead of us.
bags and suitcases that you take on a journey
We have to get our luggage when we get off the plane.
a nearby place is not far away
Let's go to a nearby restaurant, shall we?
not far from where you are
to put your things into a bag, case, or box so that you can take or send them somewhere
He was still packing his suitcase when the taxi came.
an official document that contains your photograph and shows which country you are a citizen of
an area next to a railway track where passengers get onto and off trains
The train to Brussels will depart from platform 3.
the system that is used for travelling or for moving goods from one place to another
Auckland's public transport system is excellent.
We hoped to reach the camp before dark.
a place where people go for a holiday
We stayed in a lovely ski resort.
something that you buy to remind you of a place that you visited on holiday or of a special event
This T-shirt with Big Ben on it will make a great souvenir.
the vehicles that are travelling in an area at a particular time
At that time of night, there was no traffic on the roads.
an occasion when you go somewhere and come back again
The whole family went on a trip to Florida.
a machine that you travel in or on, especially one with an engine that travels on roads, for example a car, bus, etc
Four vehicles were involved in the accident.

sections.title: Phrasal Verbs
rows: I hurt my head as I was getting into the car.
You need to get off the bus opposite the supermarket.
You can buy a ticket when you get on the bus.
Quick! Get out of the car!
Why don't you just go away and leave me alone?
I can't wait to go back to Italy.
Go to sleep because we're setting off early in the morning.
to leave the ground / to remove (a piece of clothing)
Let's go and watch the planes taking off while we wait...

sections.title: Prepositional Phrases
rows: The best way to get there is by bus.
The ship left as soon as all the passengers were on board.
Can we go from the hotel to the beach on foot, or is it better to take a bus?
Isn't it great to finally be on holiday?
We used to live on the coast.

sections.title: Word Patterns
rows: The Town Hall is quite close to my house.
This area is famous for cheese and pasta.
Let's have dinner as soon as we arrive at the hotel.
I hope it's not raining when we arrive in Manchester.
Why don't you ask your dad about the party?
Is the cinema far from here?
Hurry up or we'll be late for school.
This film is not suitable for children under the age of 15.
Ed asked for a pencil, so I lent him one.
What are those people looking at?
How do you prepare for a big match?
The college provides all the students with books.
Are you waiting for a taxi?

sections.title: Word Formation
rows: The south of England is really attractive at this time of year.
The old castle is probably the most popular attraction in this area.
Which direction did he go in?
Have you ever tried running backwards?
I can't believe you drove all the way to Paris.
Can electric cars be driven on the roads in the UK?
I asked the taxi driver to slow down.
Sylvia finally chose chocolate ice cream.
Take the book you have chosen and get it stamped by the librarian.
You have a choice - you can either have strawberry or chocolate ice cream.
A bird flew past the window.
Have you ever flown in such a small plane?
Our flight leaves at three in the morning.
That sofa looks very comfortable, doesn't it?
After four hours on the plane, I was beginning to feel uncomfortable.
If you're an experienced traveller, you'll know how important it is to be organised.
British Airways announces the departure of flight BA 632 to Moscow.
The zoo has about 250,000 visitors a year.
